metadata.title: Nano-zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide/ nanocellulose composite for the adsorption and photo catalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin hydrochloride from aqueous solutions

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Regular Article
Nano-zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide/ nanocellulose composite for the adsorption and photo catalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin hydrochloride from aqueous solutions
T.S. Anirudhan, J.R. Deepa
PII: S0021-9797(16)30919-5 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.11.042 Reference: YJCIS 21770
To appear in: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Received Date: 21 August 2016 Revised Date: 24 October 2016 Accepted Date: 12 November 2016
Please cite this article as: T.S. Anirudhan, J.R. Deepa, Nano-zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide/ nanocellulose composite for the adsorption and photo catalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin hydrochloride from aqueous solutions, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science (2016), doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2016.11.042
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Nano-zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide/ nanocellulose composite for
the adsorption and photo catalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin hydrochloride
from aqueous solutions
T. S. Anirudhan*, J.R. Deepa
Department of Chemistry, School of Physical and Mathematical Sciences, University of Kerala, Kariavattom, Trivandrum-695 581, India.
________________________________________________________________________
*Corresponding author. E-mail: tsani@rediffmail.com.Tel.: +91 471 2416472; fax: +0471 2307158.
Abstract
Purpose of this study is to report the synthetic procedure of a novel photo catalyst, nano
zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide/ nanocellulose (ZnO-GO/NC) for the effective adsorption and subsequent photo degradation of ciprofloxacin (CF), an antibiotic widely used in the poultry. Self cleaning property in cellulose was achieved by introducing a nano zinc oxide incorporated graphene oxide into nanocellulose (NC) matrix. By incorporating nano zinc oxide (ZnO) in graphene oxide (GO), band gap could be tuned to 2.4 eV and after the composite formation with NC, the band gap was enhanced to 2.8 eV which is in the visible region. Thus the degradation of the CF was achieved under the visible light. Photo degradation was due to electron hole interaction. The step wise modification in the synthesis ZnO-GO/NC was characterized using FT-IR, XRD, SEM, EDS, AFM, DRS-UV and BET N2 adsorption isotherm techniques. The values of surface area, pore volume and pore radius were found to be 12.68 m 2 /g, 0.026 mL/g and 12.5 nm, respectively. Efficiency in the adsorption process of CF onto ZnO-GO/NC was verified by batch adsorption technique. The optimum pH was found to be 5.5 and dose of the ZnO-GO/NC was optimized as 2.0 g/L. Equilibrium was attained at 120 min and the adsorption of drug followed second-order kinetics. Sips isotherm was the best fitted model and could explain the nature of interaction of CF with ZnO-GO/NC. The studies revealed that the degradation followed first-order kinetics and the optimum pH for the degradation process was found to be 6.0 and achieved a maximum degradation efficiency of 98.0 %. The reusability of ZnO-GO/NC after five consecutive cycles indicated it to be a potential candidate for the removal and degradation of CF from aquatic environment.
Key words: Graphene oxide, Nanocellulose, nano zinc oxide, Adsorption isotherm, Photocatalytic degradation, Ciprofloxacin.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Increased consumption of pharmaceutical compounds, mainly antibiotics in veterinary for
food production lead to its accumulation in surrounding environment [1-2]. They have been detected in aquatic environment and reached the environment via different routes like: human or animal wastes, pharmaceutical manufacturing plants effluents, wastes of nursing home, hospital wastewater, and animal fertilizer industries and through municipal waste water treatment plants and also from poultry farms [3-4] CF, a second generation flouroqunoline antibiotic is widely used for the treatment of a number of bacterial infections. Efficient tissue penetration and their availability in both oral and intravenous formulations [5-6] enhanced their usage in poultry, which is one of the world’s fast growing sources of meat production. In veterinary medicines, CF is often recommended for respiratory, gastrointestinal tract and urinary tract infection caused by Campylobacter. This accumulation could transform the native flora of soil and water into sources of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, and can become very harmful to human and animal health [7-9].
The antibiotics pollutants have to be removed from the wastewater before pouring into river
water bodies. Among the removal techniques, adsorption is the widely accepted due to its cost effectiveness, ease to handle, reproducibility and the availability of the different adsorbent [10- 15] and is reported as effective method for the removal of CF [16]. Considering new environmental situation, adsorbent with hazardous waste materials should undergo further treatment prior to disposal. A technology with higher efficiency and lower energy consumption are required for the disposal of the adsorbed materials and is gaining interest in intensive research. Advance oxidation processes (AOPs), based on the production of very reactive species, like hydroxyl radicals (OH . ), which can oxidize organic pollutants non-selectively and spontaneously. AOPs involve the formation of the non-toxic inorganic salts formed by the
reduction of highly toxic contaminants. Among the number of AOPs, photo-catalysis is proved to be the most important one. Photo catalytic reaction takes place when semiconductor particle absorbs a photon of light which is more energetic than its band gap [17]. Thus the electron is excited from the valance band to conduction band, hole-electron pair recombination take place, ,which could initiate the oxidation and reduction process of adsorbed substrates. In aqueous solutions the holes are scavenged by surface hydroxyl groups to generate strongly oxidizing hydroxyl radical (OH . ), which can promote the oxidation of organic compounds.
Semiconductor photo catalysis has much attention recently due to its promising
application in chemical conversion hydrogen production, refractory pollutants elimination and self-cleaning surface [18-19]. Various forms of biomasses, such as plants, trees, tunicate and bacteria, also contain cellulose having application in many spheres of modern industry [15] and can be used as effective remover of organic pollutants from the wastewater.
On converting cellulose to NC, adsorption efficiency is enhanced due to increased
surface area, number of available functional moieties and crystalline nature. NC regarded as the next generation renewable reinforcement for the production of high performance bio-composites. Though NC do not having self-cleaning activity on incorporating substances having photo catalytic degradation, self-cleaning activity can be introduced in the cellulose. GO, a highly oxidized form of graphene have various oxygen functionalities like phenol, hydroxyl and epoxy groups mainly at the basal plane and carboxylic acid groups at the edges. GO is used as reinforcement agents for the preparation of nano composites with different polymers for the removal of various pollutants from effluents. Also GO based semiconductor nano-composite photo-catalysts are mainly focused on “nonselective” degradation of pollutants.
GO can easily be mixed with different polymers and other materials, which has attracted
because of its band gap and conductivity, enhanced properties of composite materials like tensile strength, elasticity, conductivity and more. Studies revealed band gap of GO, nearly equal to 1.79 eV, acted as p-type semiconductor photo catalyst [21], but photo catalytic activity is not in the visible range. Nano-ZnO, having excellent properties and band gap around 3.37eV enhances the photo catalytic properties. On doping GO with nano ZnO, band gap will be tuned around2.12.9eV range. With this band gap range photo catalytic process occurred on visible light [22]. ZnO-GO nano composite features a good interfacial contact via a simple two-step wet chemistry approach. The reported works reveal the photocatalytic activity of ZnO/ rGO based photocatalysts [39]. Introduction of ZnO-GO on to the NC, increases the amorphous nature of the composite , thereby increasing the efficiency of the adsorption of antibiotic. Due to the increased surface area and porosity of the ZnO-GO/ NC through the composite formation of ZnO-GO with NC, leads the enhancement of adsorption as well as the photocatalytic degradation of CF [33] in visible region.
The purpose of the present work is the synthesis of novel adsorbent, nano-zinc oxide
incorporated-graphene oxide/nano cellulose composite (ZnO-GO/NC), for the removal of antibiotic CF, a pharmaceutical contaminant in waste water treatment and subsequent degradation of the adsorbed CF by the photochemical degradation in the visible light. Adsorbent before and after the adsorption process was characterized using FTIR, DRS-UV Spectroscopy, SEM, XRD and AFM analysis. The adsorption conditions for the adsorbent were optimized by varying several experimental parameters such as pH, contact time, initial concentration and adsorbent dose, temperature by batch adsorption method. Photo catalytic degradation studies were done for optimize the pH, time and the kinetic model for the degradation.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text: Ciprofloxacin (CF) was purchased from Sigma, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COOH)2H2O) and methanol from Fluka Chemie (Switzerland). Graphite powder, crystalline- 300 mesh, 99% Alfa Aesar, , sulphuric acid (H2SO4) (99%), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), cellulose, sodium nitrate (NaNO3) was purchased from E-Merck, India Ltd.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of ZnO-GO/NC photo catalyst
sections.text:
Preparation of the adsorbent involved four steps. The detailed procedure regarding the
synthesis of the photo catalyst is as shown in Scheme.1. GO was synthesized by modified Hummers and Offman’s method [23]. ZnO nanosol was prepared as follows: about 0.01M zinc acetate di hydrate was dissolved in methanol and heated to 50 0 C for half an hour, making precursor solution, A. 0.02M NaOH was dissolved in methanol, making precursor solution, B and was added drop wise under constant stirring into A, for half an hour and was heated to 50 0 C for half an hour. After stirring for 2h and cooling at room temperature, homogeneous transparent ZnO was prepared. Nano cellulose was prepared from cellulose by sulphuric acid hydrolysis [24]. GO prepared from the modified Hummers method was sonicated with the prepared ZnO nano sol. After 15 minutes of sonication, the mixture was placed at 70 0 C, and then at 150 0 C for 15 minutes to complete the formation of ZnO/GO and was rinsed with deionized water. About 5 g NC was dispersed in 100 mL distilled water and was sonicated with ZnO-GO for 1 hour. The mixing (1mL/1mL) was done by ultra-sonication bath for 20 min at room temperature.
During the synthesis of the photocatalyst, ZnO-GO/NC, the amount of ZnO: GO: NC was kept as 0.5: 1.0:1.5 weight (gram) ratios. For the optimization of the amount of GO in the ZnOGO/NC, different weight percentages of GO were used in the synthesis of photocatalyst with other two, in the fixed concentration. From the experimental results, a graph (S.Fig.1.) was plotted with weight percentage composition of GO with photodegradation ability and it is clear that 33.3% of GO is sufficient for the effective photodegradation of CF from the aqueous solution.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of CF- ZnO-GO/NC
sections.text:
100 ml of the 4mg/L of CF solution was taken in 250 mL Erlenmeyer flasks. Then it was
shaken with 200 mg of synthesized ZnO-GO/NC in water bath shaker for 3 h in dark condition and the supernatant solution drained off. The composite dried in hot air oven and used in the characterization as CF-ZnO-GO/NC.
2.4.Instruments of characterization
FTIR spectra of the adsorbent materials were taken with Cary 630 model FTIR, Agilent
Technology operating a frequency range from 600 to 4000 cm -1 in transmission mode. The pH measurements were made on systronics µ-pH meter (Model 361). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were examined using Siemens D5005 X- Ray unit. Cu K∞ (λ=1.54064 Å) radiation generated a voltage of 40 KV and a current of 40 mA was used as X-ray source. Scanning electron microscopy/Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy or EDS (SEM/EDS) analyses were done using Nova Nano SEM NPEP 252 High resolution FE-scanning electron microscope/ Bruker. Atomic force microscope (AFM) images were recorded on Bruker DIMENSION edge with SCAN ASYST instrument by taping mode. The absorbance measurements were performed on a JASCO -530 UV- visible spectrophotometer. Temperature
controlled water bath shaker (Lab line instruments Pvt Ltd Kochi, India) with a temperature tolerance ±1 o C was used for performing batch mode kinetic and isotherm experiments. For photo catalytic degradation studies, solar simulator, A1Solar light line, Science tech1450, Globaldrive, London, has intensity100 Mw/cm 2 . Quantachrome NovaWin - Data acquisition and reduction for nova instruments©1994-2007, 300 0 C using Nitrogen gas for surface area analysis
2.4. Adsorption experiments
Batch experiments were performed by equilibrating 0.05 g of adsorbent with 25 ml CF
solutions of predetermined initial concentrations. By adding NaOH and HCl of different concentrations, initial pH of the solutions was maintained at the required pH value. The suspensions were shaken for 3 h. The solid and liquid phases were separated by centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 15 min. The CF concentrations in liquid phase were determined by UV/Visible Spectrophotometer at 266 nm. The amount of CF adsorbed in (mg/g) at equilibrium (qe) was calculated using mass balance equation.
Whereas C0 and Ce are the initial and final concentration of CF in the solutions in (mg/L),’V’ is the volume of the aqueous solution (mL) and W is the weight of ZnO-GO/NC (g) [15]. All the adsorption experiments were done in triplicates and mean cumulative values were represented. The difference in results for triplicate measurements was less than 3.0%

sections.heading: 2.5 Photo catalytic degradation of CF
sections.text:
The photo catalytic degradation of CF was done using Solar Simulator, A1Solar light line
having the intensity100 Mw/ cm 2 . Two different concentrations of CF (2.0, 4.0 mg/L) solution were taken in Erlenmeyer flasks (250 mL capacity), containing added 2 g/L of the adsorbent and their initial pH of the solution was adjusted. Then adsorption experiments were done in dark for 90 min to obtain equilibrium adsorption of CF onto the photo catalyst. After this, the concentration of CF was measured using UV-visible spectrophotometer at 266 nm, which is considered as C0 (mg/L) at t = 0 for photo catalytic degradation experiment. The solution with the adsorbent was placed in the solar simulator in a wide vessel having specific surface area. The solutions were withdrawn at definite time intervals to determine the concentration of CF. The percentage removal of CF from the solution at different time intervals due to photo degradation was calculated using the equation,
The effect of solution pH and presence of inorganic ions on the photo degradation efficiency of the photo catalyst was tested.
All adsorption experiments were carried out in triplicate with standard deviation less than 2.0%. The experimental data should be selected within the range of standard deviation of 2.0 %. The kinetic and isotherm parameters were obtained by a linear regression analysis using Origin pro 8.0software.

sections.heading: 3. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
3.2. Characterization of the adsorbent 3.2.1. FTIR Analysis
𝐷𝑒𝑔𝑟𝑎𝑑𝑒𝑑𝐶𝐹 % = 100 − 𝑐0−𝑐𝑡
𝑐0 𝑥100 (3)
The FTIR patterns of Graphite, GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC, CF and CF-ZnO-GO/NC
are depicted in Fig.1. Graphite showed peaks between 1305- 1505 cm−1 corresponding to aromatic C=C stretching vibration [24]. The spectrum of GO shows characteristic peak at 1730 cm-1owing to C=O stretching and 1057cm-1due to C-O stretching in the functional groups with peaks resembling to reported work [25] . ZnO stretching vibrations gave rise to transmission band depending on the adjacent attached functional groups in ZnO-GO. Peaks were red-shifted due to oxygen containing groups and intensity changed indicating that the modification took place in GO. In the spectrum of NC, characteristic peaks of O-H stretching vibration, C-H bending and C-H stretching of CH2 group was observed at 3300, 1626 and 2900cm-1, respectively. Peaks at 3303 and 1326 cm-1 correspond to C=O stretching dispersion of stacked GO layers in NC. In the FTIR spectra of CF, prominent peaks were found at 3518 and 3352 cm-1 assigned to stretching vibration of -OH groups and intermolecular hydrogen bonding respectively. Peaks at 1692 and 1624 cm -1 were attributed to quinolones. Strong absorption peaks at 1134 and 923.0 cm-1 were attributed to CF adsorption [27] and retained, indicating the stability of the adsorbent even after the adsorption of CF. In the IR spectrum of CF-.ZnOGO/NC new peaks appeared at 1647, 1459 and 1319 cm-1 are due to C=O stretch, C–H bend and C–H wag (–CH2F) of CF. These modifications in the IR spectrum of CF-ZnO-GO/NC compared to ZnO-GO/NC confirm the interaction of CF on to the ZnO-GO/NC. 3.2.2. X-ray diffraction method The XRD pattern of graphite, GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC, CF - ZnO/GO/NC were shown in Fig .2. XRD pattern of graphite shows only one clear peak at 26.430 and GO gives broad peak between 9.00-12.000 belongs to the (001) reflection of GO and the inter layer spacing is much greater than graphite, which could explain the introduction of oxygen functionalities on the
graphite surfaces. The formation of new peaks also substantiate the conversion of graphite to GO [28,29]. In the diffraction pattern of ZnO-GO, the diffraction peak of GO dropped profoundly to an undetectable manner [30] may be due to the exfoliation of GO sheets and the regular structure of GO due to the introduction of ZnO on to the GO. Peaks at 22.10, 25.82, 30.34, 35.00 of ZnOGO layers by the introduction of ZnO into the sheets of GO, resembles to the reported work [39]. NC showed diffraction maxima around 22.860 as reported elsewhere [15]. In ZnO-GO/NC, broad peaks at 16.33 and 22.000 substantiate the amorphous nature of composite. XRD peaks of ZnO-GO are not present in the spectrum of ZnO-GO/NC, and almost retain the spectrum of NC with slight modification. The value of d-spacing calculated from the NC spectrum also confirms that ZnO-GO incorporated inside the NC. In the CF loaded adsorbent, peak appeared at 9.210 confirms the adsorption of CF and the reduction of peak intensity at the 22.670 explains amorphous nature through CF adsorption on to the ZnO-GO/NC the surface.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. SEM and EDS Analysis
sections.text:
The SEM images of Cellulose, NC, GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC, CF- ZnO-GO/NC are
shown in Fig.3. Cellulose fibers show a cylindrical shape as reported elsewhere. Surface of pristine cellulosic fiber was clean and smooth [31]. NC exhibits a rode like morphology. Size of the rods was converted to nano range in the SEM image. The GO sheet appeared to be stacked and there are many wrinkles through all the surfaces. The severe agglomeration of GO sample may be due to its enormous oxygen functionalities on the surface. From the SEM image of ZnO/GO, surface morphology change which on comparing with GO gave the evidence for the formation of ZnO-GO. ZnO-GO/NC image, porous nature of the composite clearly indicated the availability of more adsorption site on the surface [32] and the formation of ZnO-GO/NC is confirmed. The SEM image of CF loaded ZnO-GO/NC shows uniformly filled the pores as white
patches confirming the adsorption of CF onto ZnO-GO/NC. Morphology change confirms drug adsorption on to the surface of the ZnO-GO/NC.
The EDS spectra of GO and ZnO-GO are given in Fig.5. In the spectra of GO, the
intensities of C and O are given and its % composition is given as 32.3 and 67.6%, respectively. In addition to C and O peak, ZnO-GO/NC has a peak of Zn with percentage composition as 7.4 %. The intensity of C and O is reduced, which indicates the modification of GO through the composite formation. EDS spectrum has provide clear idea about the incorporation of ZnO in the GO in the composite ZnO-GO/NC

sections.heading: 3.2.4. AFM Analysis
sections.text:
AFM images of GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC, CF- ZnO-GO/NC with topology 5x5 nm are shown in Fig.4. GO shows a sheet-like morphology. In the AFM image of ZnO-GO, sheet morphology changed to a film like appearance, and the height sensor indicates that modification occurred in the surface morphology. This confirms the modification took place through doping of ZnO in the GO structure. Modification during the composite formation of ZnO-GO/NC is evident by the AFM image which could substantiate SEM data. Increase in width of the particle in the AFM image of ZnO-GO/ NC, is due to the composite formation of ZnO-GO with NC. The interaction of the CF with the ZnO-GO/NC considerably changed the AFM image of ZnOGO/NC . This morphological change may be due to entrapping of CF in the ZnO-GO/NC as well as they interact in the electron rich moieties of the ZnO-GO/NC.
3.2.5. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopic analysis
The optical properties of GO, ZnO-GO, and ZnO-GO/NC, were investigated using UV-
visible spectroscopy, adsorption of GO is below the visible range (S.Fig.2) ZnO was doped with GO for enhancing to visible region activity, NC made a composite with the ZnO-GO as it was retained in the visible region absorption. Kubelka-Munk (K-M) equation at any wave length can be written as
Where F(Rα) is known as K–M function, where Rα = R sample/R standard
When the material scatters in perfectly diffuse manner the K–M absorption coefficient K
become equal to 2α when material scatter perfectly diffused manner [17], α is linear adsorption coefficient of material which obtained from scattering and reflectance spectrum. According to KM theory, S is the constant with respect to wave length.
The band gap energies of GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC and CF-ZnO-GO/NC obtained from Kubelka- munk plot were found to be 1.77, 2.40, 2.79, 2.88 respectively (S.Fig.3). Thus, absorption of final composite ZnO-GO/NC is in the visible region due to the significant blue shift compared to that of GO and this may be due to the doping of ZnO species perfectly on the graphene oxide, enhances the photo catalytic activity under visible light due to electron transfer process, between ZnO-GO/NC and CF.

3.2.6. Point of Zero charge
Exactly 0.1 g of ZnO-GO/NC dispersed in 50 mL of 0.1 M NaCl. The volumes of acid
and alkali required for the variation for pH were measured. Point of zero charge (PZC) can be arrived by the equation:
σo is the surface charge density, F is the Faraday constant(96485C/g equiva),𝐶 and are the concentration of strong acid and base. [H + ] and [OH - ] are the equilibrium concentration of H + and OH - ions bound to the suspension surface (equiv./L). σo (Coulombs/cm 2 ) against pH plotted for ZnO-GO/NC (S.Fig.4). σo is equal to zero at the particular pH and is taken as pH pzc. The point of zero charge was found to be 3.0, which corresponds to the fact that surface of ZnOGO/NC negative above 3.0 and positive below 3.0. 3.2.7. Pore specification and surface area analysis
Quantachrome Nova Win - Data acquisition and reduction for nova instruments©1994-
2007, 300 0 C using Nitrogen gas adsorption isotherm technique was used for surface characterization of the photocatalyst. Bath temperature was77.3 K and the tolerance of the instrument was 0.100/0.100 (ads/des). Equilibrium time was 60/60 sec (ads/des) and equilibrium timeout was 240/240 sec (ads/des) with analysis time, 202.7 min. The N2 adsorption –desorption isotherm at 77.3 K and the pore size distribution plot can be calculated by Barret-Halenda (BHJ) method. On plotting cumulative surface area against pore radius in (S.Fig.5), the values of the surface area, pore volume and pore radius were obtained as 12.683 m 2 /g, 0.026 cc/g and 12.5 nm.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Effect of adsorbent dose on adsorption of CF on to ZnO-GO/NC
sections.text:
Experiments were executed with various amounts of adsorbent ranging between0.05 to
5.0 g/L by keeping identical the experimental condition (S.Fig.6.). The increased adsorption capacity was observed with increase in adsorbent dose, might be due to the unsaturation of adsorption sites [33], Adsorption efficiency of the ZnO-GO/NC is higher compared to that ZnO/GO, reached a saturation level at high doses. This could be explained as a consequence of partial aggregation of ZnO/GO/NC, at higher concentration, leads a decrease in the available adsorption site. For the complete removal CF from 1 L aqueous solution, a minimum dosage of 2.0 g was only required. So the adsorbent dose for the adsorption of CF onto the ZnO/GO/NC system was minimized to 2.0 g / L. 3.3.2. Optimization of pH in adsorption of CF on to ZnO-GO/NC
pH has significant effect on the adsorption capacity of ZnO-GO/NC for CF drug. For
this, aqueous solutions of CF with different pH values ranging from 2.0 to 9.0 were prepared having CF concentrations of 2.0 mg/L and 4.0 mg/L. The pH of the solution was adjusted using HCl and NaOH solutions having 0.1 molar concentrations. The value of adsorption is affected by the value of pH variation. ZnO-GO/NC, concentration was selected as 2.0 g/L. A graph was plotted with adsorption percentage of CF against equilibrium pH of the solutions (Fig.6). The adsorption behavior of the carboxyl functionalized adsorbent depends on the degree of protonation and de protonation in acidic moieties [34]. At lower pH values, the adsorption capacity was found to be decreased due to the less interaction between CF ions and H + ions. But
as pH increased, adsorption capacity also slowly increased, due to the ionization of –COOH groups on the surface of the GO. It was observed from graph that an increase in adsorption percentage up to 5.5 and then a gradual decrease. The maximum adsorption of CF on to the adsorbent ZnO-GO/NC occurred at pH 5.5 and decreases with increasing or decreasing pH. At pH 5.5, 2 mg/L CF got 98.6% and for 4 mg/L it was 96.7 % adsorption capacity. Maximum adsorption capacity may be due to the electrostatic interaction between reactive species present in the adsorbent surface and lone pair of electrons and fluorine like reactive species present in the CF surface [17]. pKa1 and pKa2 value of CF reported to be 6.1 and 8.5, respectively. Hence at the pH 5.5, CF can act as positive species which in turn interact effectively with negative surface of the composite.
3.3.3. CF adsorption kinetics on to ZnO-GO/NC
Rate of adsorption require a major concern while designing a treatment plant. The effect
of contact time on the adsorption of CF on to ZnO-GO/NC was studied in the concentration range 2.0-8.0 mg/L and the outcome of the experiments are shown in Fig.7. The equilibrium time reached at 120 min. The adsorption rate was higher in the initial stage may be due to greater number of available reaction sites for the adsorption of CF. The kinetic data were analyzed using the pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order equations respectively:
𝑞 𝑞 − 𝑒 (7)
𝑞
(8)
where qe and qt are the amounts of solute adsorbed per unit mass of the adsorbent at equilibrium and time t (min) respectively, k1 is the pseudo-first-order rate constant (min -1 ) and k2 is the
pseudo-second-order rate constant of adsorption (g/mg/min).With increase of initial concentration CF from 2.0 to 8.0 mg/L, the adsorption capacity increased from 0.94 to 3.70 mg/g, indicating CF adsorption depended on initial concentration. The increase in the adsorption capacity at higher concentration is due to the difference in the concentration of CF in liquid and solid phase, which is the driving force. The pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second-order kinetic parameters were analyzed from the experimental data using non-linear curve fitting procedure and the results are given in Table 1.Theoretical lines were constructed using constants. Adsorption is rapid in the initial stage which may be due to concentration gradient and more available adsorption sites. The pseudo-first-order equation indicated a poor correlation with experimental data, whereas the pseudo-second-order equation proved a good correlation of the experimental results. Also the values of R 2 and χ 2 listed in Table 1 reflect a better correlation for the pseudo-second-order model. The rate constant k2 decreases from 1.47 to 0.22g/mg/min when the concentration increases from 2.0 to 8.0 mg/L, due to the absence of intermediate state formation during the adsorption process, sorption is controlled by intra particle pore diffusion or pore diffusion and the antibiotic adsorption had occurred only at the surface of the adsorbent. The experimental and calculated values of adsorption capacity agreed very well confirming physical adsorption mechanism possible for the adsorption of CF ions onto ZnO-GO/NC [15]. Adsorption rate was inversely proportional to the surface loading. Pseudo-second-order mechanism proposed , at lower the concentration of CF in the solution, lower probability of the collision between them. CF and functional groups on the ZnO-GO/NC could interact very fast by bond formation between them.
3.3.4. CF adsorption isotherm studies on to ZnO-GO/NC
The experimental data of equilibrium adsorption were analyzed using the non-linear forms
(Fig.8.). Langmuir, Freundlich and Sips isotherm equations as follows;
Where qe and Ce are the adsorption capacity and equilibrium concentrations when an adsorbate gets adsorbed onto the adsorbent and Q o and b are Langmuir constants. KF (function of energy of adsorption and temperature) and 1/n (also called as the heterogeneity coefficient) are the Freundlich constants. When, 1/n < 1, the adsorbent material is heterogeneous in nature. Qs, is the Sips maximum adsorption capacity, Ks is the Sips equilibrium constant and 1/ns is the exponent.The isotherm constants were calculated using non-linear regression analysis and the results are listed in Table.2. On verifying the results, equilibrium data agreed well with the Sips model. The values of R 2 and χ 2 showed that the adsorption of CF ions onto ZnO-GO/NC was best fitted with Sips isotherm model over the concentration ranges studied. Sips isotherm model , combination of Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherm models [35]. The value of Qmax values obtained from Sips model is higher than Langmuir model. Hence, the higher concentration, Sips favors Langmuir model and at the lower concentration favors Freundlich model. The R 2 values for all the three isotherms models were beyond 0.90 which substantially indicate the suitability of these models in explaining adsorption mechanism. Lower values of χ 2 and higher values of R 2 show a very good mathematical agreement with Sips isotherm model at different temperature range 20- 50 0 C indicates multilayer adsorption at lower concentration of CF and monolayer at higher concentration on to the adsorbent material.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Effect of pH on photo degradation
sections.text:
Like the adsorption of CF onto the photo catalyst, photo degradation capability of the
photo catalyst also depends on the solution pH [36].The experiment was conducted using 2.0, 4.0 and 8.0 mg/L of CF solutions. pH of the supernatant solution after adsorption was adjusted in the range 4.0–12.0 before photo catalytic degradation to know the effect of pH on the CF degradation (Fig.9). From the graph it is clear that at lower pH values, the degradation of CF was not so easy .The photo degradation efficiency of the photo catalyst increased to98.0% when the pH increased from 2.0 to 6.0. There is electrostatic interaction of CF with the surface functional groups of photo catalyst, ZnO-GO/NC throughout this pH range. The adsorption of CF molecules on the surface of photo catalyst facilitates its easy degradation. When the pH value ranges from 6.5 to 9.0, the degradation efficiency decreased from 98.0 to 52.3% reduced the interaction between the CF molecule and the photo catalyst may cause the decreased efficiency. Besides, other ions may compete with drug molecules for the vacant sites in the photo catalyst created in the adsorbent after the degradation of adsorbed CF molecules. 3.4.2. Kinetics of the photo degradation studies
To explain enhanced photo degradation efficiency of ZnO-GO/NC with CF, kinetic
experiments of photo degradation CF is done with contrastive experiments without catalyst, with GO, ZnO-GO, ZnO-GO/NC. The experimental results are summarized in the Fig.10. A, B, C. From the Figure, it was evident that there was nil photo degradation process of blank CF (without photo catalyst).In presence of GO, CF slightly degraded after 100 minutes. Though a number of oxygen containing groups and large surface area for GO slow reaction rate might be due to the electron accumulation on the GO surface and the recombination of GO with CF .+ . ZnO-GO could
enhance the degradation and almost completed with 60 minutes. However ZnO-GO/NC showed prominent degradation ability and 98.0% CF degraded with in the 40 minutes. This fact could substantiate by UV/Visible spectra of the CF solution and after 40 minute, peak at271 nm almost completely disappeared with in 40 minute. The experimental data verified using kinetic models and best correlated was first order kinetic model [36]. Linear regression analysis was done using with the help of origin pro.8 software with integrated rate law equation
C0 and C are the concentration of CF on the ZnO-GO/NC; K is the rate constant (min -1 ). Smaller value of the standard deviation and the value of R 2 indicate suitability of the First-order kinetic model for the degradation process. Figure shows good straight line suggesting first order kinetics. The values of rate constant for blank CF, GO, ZnO-GO, and ZnO-GO/NC are 7.89x10 -4 ,1.5x10 -3 , 5.1 x10 -2 , 9.49 x10 -2 min -1 ,respectively, indicates the significantly high photo degradation efficiency of ZnO-GO/NC. 3.4.3. Mechanism of photo degradation
The proposed mechanism of the photo degradation happens on the surface of ZnO-
GO/NC is explained in the Scheme.2. CF- ZnO-GO/NC on irradiating with visible light having photon energy higher than its band gap (2.8 eV) leads the formation of valence band electrons and the conduction band holes .These charges move towards the surface during the degradation process. The CF on excitation could act as light sensitizer as well as electron acceptor [37-39]. In the process of the photosensitization the CF adsorbed on the ZnO-GO/NC surface is excited by visible light, and act as photo sensitizer and the molecule can eject electrons onto the conduction band of ZnO-GO/NC system. The reaction mechanism can be depicted as:
𝑙𝑛 𝐶0
𝐶 = 𝐾𝑡 (12)
The oxidized form of the CF molecules will then undergo further degradation to yield degraded products. In the present photo catalytic system, due to the presence of COOH and –OH groups the material can easily absorb the CF molecules which favor the photo catalytic degradation.
During photo oxidation process, irradiation with light energy higher than the band gap (h), ZnO-GO/NC generates a pair of conduction band electron (e -
CB) and valence band holes
(h + VB).Then these charge carriers migrate to the particle surface, where they can recombine or can be trapped at some defect sites, thereby initiating oxidation and reduction processes of the adsorbed substrate
Surface modification of NC with ZnO-GO increases the ability to photo degradation of
CF molecules. The presence of COOH and OH, epoxide groups in GO helps in the successful adsorption of CF molecules on the surface of the adsorbent and can act as electron sink which could prevent the recombination e - hole pair and holes accumulate on CB of ZnO-GO/NC, The CF adsorbed in the NC also excited along with other CF and electrons transferred to the conduction band of ZnO via transportation in GO sheet hence theses electrons combines rapidly with adsorbed oxygen and water on the surface of ZnO-GO/NC and created highly reactive and oxidizing species like hydroxyl radical (O . H - ), superoxide radical anion (O2 .- ), photo generated
holes and electrons selectively degrade, oxidize or reduce the CF molecules adsorbed on the surface of the adsorbent to nontoxic gases like CO2 and H2O as equations depicted below.
ZnO-GO/NC + hν ZnO- GO/NC (e - CB + h + VB) (13)
CF + hν 1 CF * or 3 CF *
(14)
1 CF * or 3 CF * + ZnO-GO/NC
1 CF * + ZnO-GO/NC (e - CB ) (15)
GO can exhibit good conductivity along the molecule and offer a set of energy levels
that can support charge transfer thereby enhancing photo degradation at pH 6.0. The major mechanism of degradation is through photo catalytic process rather than photolysis of the CF molecules as the drug was found to be stable in sunlight
.
3.5. Regeneration and reusability of photo catalyst
Regeneration and recyclability of the adsorbent is a crucial factor for the practical applications, however it is important to determine the stability of photo catalyst during photo catalytic reaction. ZnO-GO/NC was tested for its regeneration and recyclability; five cycles of the photo catalytic experiment with ZnO-GO/NC composite were carried out in visible region using 0.5 g of the adsorbent loaded with aqueous solution of CF (0.4 g/L). The initial amount of the ZnOGO/NC, was taken for the first cycle was reused in every cycle. After each cycle’s photodegradation process, the adsorbent separated from the solution by ultra-centrifugation and washed in saxhlet apparatus with water as solvent till the absorption peak of CF (266 nm) was not present in the solvent. By checking weight of ZnO-GO/NC after each cycle, a decrease in the
ZnO-GO/NC (e - CB ) + O2 O2 .- + ZnO-GO/NC (16)
ZnO-GO/NC (h + VB) + H2O ZnO-GO/NC + H + + OH - (17) O2 . - + H + HO2 .+ (18)
ZnO-GO/NC (h + VB) + OH - ZnO-GO/NC + OH . (19)
OH . + CF H2O + CO2 (20)
weight was experienced due to the cleaning and separation process. This decrease in weight may cause the adsorption reduced from 99.6% on first usage to 92.1 % after the fifth cycle of reuse (Fig.11). A corresponding reduction in photo catalytic degradation capacity of the adsorbent was also observed from first cycle to fifth cycle (98.0 - 84.3%). CF could be completely decomposed in each cycle and the ZnO-GO/NC photo catalyst not exhibited much significant change in its photo catalytic activity during the repeated photo catalytic experiments. Results could conclude that the photo catalyst is suitable for reuse and hence it can be used for practical purposes as a photo catalyst.

sections.heading: 3.7. Feasibility of photo catalyst in the degradation of antibiotic from wastewater
sections.text:
Wastewater samples were collected from ponds near to poultry farm (sample I), stream
near to animal farm house (Sample II) and pond near to slaughter house (Sample III) and the presence of CF in treated wastewater determined [Table.3]. In order to avoid the formation of complexes between CF and the organic matter present in the sample, a buffer solution was prepared with 0.05M NaH2PO4.H2O and 0.05 M citric acid in water was used. Samples were filtered with 4.5 cm- diameter, 1.2 lm-pore size glass–fibre filters (Millipore, Billerica, MA, USA). The samples were prepared for analysis as follows:
pH of the solution was adjusted to 5.5, followed by the centrifugation at 2500 rpm for 10
min, transfer of 25 mL supernatant liquid into a 50 mL flask for the quantitative of CF analysis was done in UV visible spectro- photometer. The composition of the sample is given in the
Table 3. The Amount of ZnO-GO/NC for the complete removal of CF is 0.40 g/L each for sample 1, and 0.45 g/L needed for sample II and III (Fig.12) which is comparable with the data obtained from the pH optimization study. The amount required is slightly higher compared with
the result obtained from pH optimization experiments, maybe due to the presence of other contaminant which could compete with the adsorption sites.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: For the adsorption and photo degradation of an antibiotic CF, a novel photo catalyst, ZnOGO/NC nano composite was successfully synthesized and the photo degradation CF from water under visible light was investigated. The enhanced photo catalytic performance of ZnO-GO nano composite due to the efficient photosensitized electron injection and repressed electron recombination in the NC due to the electron-transfer process with GO as electron collector and transporter. These features make the ZnO-GO/NC composite as a recommendable candidate for applications relating environmental aqueous pollution. Photo catalyst, prepared was characterized by means of SEM, AFM, XRD, FTIR, DRS and potentiometric techniques. Optimum pH was found to be 5.5 and adsorbent dose was 2.0 g/L. Adsorption kinetic data were best fitted with pseudo-second-order kinetic model suggesting interaction of CF on to ZnOGO/NC as hydrogen bonding as well as ionic. The adsorption isotherm data were fitted with Sips isotherm model. Regeneration and recyclability of the adsorbent was tested for five cycles. The feasibility of the photo catalyst in the real life situation was performed using water samples collected from water source near to poultry farms. The method of synthesis may be extended to design more graphene composites for various applications in the field of catalysts, bio-molecule sensor, and nano-electronic devices. These features make the ZnO-GO/NC composite as a recommendable candidate for applications relating to environmental aqueous pollution.

references.title: Standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater, 22 edn
author: A W W APHA
AW E

referenceMentions.context: Efficient tissue penetration and their availability in both oral and intravenous formulations [5-6] enhanced their usage in poultry, which is one of the world’s fast growing sources of meat production. In veterinary medicines, CF is often recommended for respiratory, gastrointestinal tract and urinary tract infection caused by Campylobacter. This accumulation could transform the native flora of soil and water into sources of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, and can become very harmful to human and animal health [7-9]. The antibiotics pollutants have to be removed from the wastewater before pouring into river water bodies. Among the removal techniques, adsorption is the widely accepted due to its cost effectiveness, ease to handle, reproducibility and the availability of the different adsorbent [1015] and is reported as effective method for the removal of CF [16].
